statement.tex: If the tangent to a curve at any point $P = (x,y)$ meets the coordinate axes at $A$ and $B$ such that $P$ is the mid-point of $AB$, then find the equation of the curve given that it passes through $(1,1)$

reason.tex:
%text If the tangent cuts the axes at $A$ and $B$ respectively and $P$ is the mid-point, then \[ \underbrace{P = \left(x,y \right) = \left(\frac{0+b}{2},\frac{0+a}{2} \right) = \left(\frac{b}{2}, \frac{a}{2} \right)}_{\text{Mid-point Rule}} \] Which means, % \begin{align}
x = \frac{b}{2}&\text{ and } y = \frac{a}{2} \\ \therefore b = 2x&\text{ and } a = 2y \end{align} %text Moreover, the \underline\text{slope of the tangent} is \[ \quad \dydx = \dfrac{a-0}{0-b} = -\frac{a}{b} = -\frac{2y}{2x} = -\frac{y}{x}\] Hence, the \underline\text{differential equation} for the curve \[ \qquad\qquad \dydx = -\frac{y}{x}\] %

options.tex:
%text
\[ \qquad\dydx = -\frac{y}{x}\implies xy = C \] And as the curve passes through $(1,1)$ \[ \qquad C =1\text{ and } xy = 1\]
\incorrect \[ \qquad\dydx = -\frac{y}{x}\implies y = e^x + C \]
And as the curve passes through $(1,1)$ \[ \qquad C = 1-e \text{ and } y = e^x + (1-e) \] %
